holidays.name: Leif Erikson Day
holidays.description: Celebrates the Norse explorer believed to be the first European to set foot in North America, predating Columbus by nearly 500 years.
holidays.origin: Established by the U.S. Congress and first officially observed in 1964. It honors Leif Erikson‚Äôs adventurous spirit.
holidays.funFact: Leif Erikson‚Äôs expedition reached an area called Vinland, which many believe to be coastal North America, around the year 1000 AD.

holidays.name: National Moldy Cheese Day
holidays.description: An ode to the wonderfully pungent world of moldy cheeses like blue cheese, Roquefort, and Camembert.
holidays.origin: An unofficial foodie observance to encourage cheese lovers to embrace the funky and flavorful molds that make some cheeses spectacular.
holidays.funFact: Blue cheese owes its distinctive veins to Penicillium roqueforti mold, which also contributed to the development of penicillin!

holidays.name: Fire Pup Day
holidays.description: A quirky celebration honoring the heroic fire dogs who assist firefighters in saving lives and property.
holidays.origin: Inspired by the devoted canines that have been a part of firefighting teams since the 18th century, celebrated mainly in firefighter communities.
holidays.funFact: Fire dogs were originally used to warn buildings of fire alarms and to help pull hoses before motorized trucks were common.

holidays.name: Oktoberfest Ends
holidays.description: Marks the closing day of the world's largest beer festival held annually in Munich, Germany, famous for lederhosen, giant pretzels, and endless beer steins.
holidays.origin: A folk festival that began in 1810 to celebrate a royal wedding, now a global symbol of Bavarian culture and merrymaking.
holidays.funFact: Despite its name, Oktoberfest actually starts in September and ends on the first Sunday in October or October 3 if that Sunday falls on the 3rd.
